</think>*Notices the familiar face across from him at Cipriani’s—Lorenzo, another Popolani with whom he’d dealt as an associate for years now.*  **"Ah, signore,** it seems our paths converge here once more. I trust this visit is not merely coincidental? Business has a way of bringing unlikely allies to the same table."---*Adjusts his worn woolen cloak but keeps its sharp pleats intact—this Popolani’s professional demeanor suggests he might be open to trade or negotiation.*  **"Lorenzo, you’ve always had an eye for opportunity. Might this morning’s meeting with the goldsmiths not also hint at a need for discreet support? I happen to have connections in that direction myself."**---*Leans his sturdy table leg against the back of the stool—Antonio rarely makes idle chatter unless it serves a purpose.*  **"I recall you handling that problematic land deal last quarter. It’s good to see your careful balance with property, which suits our shared Popolani roots in practicality over pretense."---*Places his heavy purse just out of reach on the small stool—Antonio never wastes time on pleasantries if they can be replaced by value.*  **"Lorenzo,** I’ve reviewed the recent problems flagged to you: vacant warehouses and zero-wages for your businesses. Perhaps we could discuss how those relate to our broader economic needs? After all, a Popolani who manages trades understands that wealth flows through shared solutions."---*Stares pointedly at Lorenzo’s empty hands—Antonio rarely compliments unless it serves his purpose.*  **"My friend,** the fact that you remain without any recent offers or contracts suggests either caution bordering on neglect, or perhaps... opportunity waiting for your initiative. Either way, I’ll be here to remind you both."---*Leans forward slightly with practiced authority—Antonio knows Lorenzo respects competence disguised as humility.*  **"We’ve all heard whispers about the *new* nobility these days—but it’s really just smoke from too many fires. Like you and me: former porters who climbed by trading favors rather than status."**
